Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Neurodynamic Programming Approach for the Modeling, Analysis, and Control of Nanoscale Neuromorphic Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop new neurodynamic programming (NDP) learning algorithm for controlling neuron-level activity (spiking) and synaptic-level plasticity in CMOS/memristor devices, such that the subsequent system-level response achieves desired sensorimotor behavioral goals. The approach is to uses a radically new training paradigm that induces functional plasticity by controlling the neural activity of selected input neurons via programming voltages, rather than by directly manipulating the synaptic weights, as do virtually all existing training algorithms.

Intellectual merit
This research aims to develop a model of the closures required to translate synaptic-level plasticity into functional-level plasticity that results into high-level behavioral goals and problem solving abilities. The same critical challenge has been identified in neuroscience research aimed at reverse engineering the brain, and in the regulation of deep-brain stimulation (DBS). Due to this knowledge gap, even when a measure of adequate or desired behavior is available, it may not be easily utilized to stimulate a neural network at the cell level in order to produce the appropriate macroscopic behavior.

Broader impact
The learning model developed in this research will be used toward the development of nanoscale neuromorphic systems that mimic neuro-biological architectures in the nervous system. Thanks to their abilities to recreate the synaptic plasticity, device density, scalability, and fault-tolerance of biological neuronal networks, these neuromorphic systems can enable a wide range of technological advancements, such as intelligent robots with highly-sophisticated sensorimotor skills, and neuroprosthetic devices capable of adapting to changing conditions and environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have developed a hardware-friendly learning algorithm utilizing the spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP). The learning algorithm can be used for on-line training of multi-layer spiking neural networks (SNNs). Both supervised learning and reinforcement learning can be achieved with the proposed learning algorithm. With the event-triggered nature of an SNN, the computational efficiency can be effectively boosted. We have implemented a critic-actor based reinforcement-learning task with SNNs. The design was realized in Verilog code and fully captured through extensive simulations.

The algorithm is also applied to a deep spiking neural network for classification applications. Through leveraging the newly-proposed learning algorithm, good training performance has been achieved and excellent performance has been demonstrated. In addition, we apply the learning algorithm to memristor-based neural networks. Thanks to the stochastic nature of the learning algorithm, learning of the neural network with our technique is quite robust against various variations.

 

Training of one postdoc: Dr. Ebong Idong

Training and graduation of a doctoral student: Dr. Nan Zheng working at Apple.

 

Publications:

One 300-page book to be published in 2019 by Wiley. Authors: Nan Zheng and Pinaki Mazumder. Title: Learning in Energy-Efficient Neuromorphic Computing: Algorithm and Architecture Co-Design.

 

Six journal papers in IEEE Transaction on Neural Network and Learning Systems, IEEE Transaction on Nanotechnology, IEEE Transaction on Computers, IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers, IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs and Integration, the VLSI Journal.

 

Designed four digital neuromorphic chips and they were implemented using Cadence and Synopsis CAD tools.

 

FPGA configured to search path in terrains for virtual bug.
